title: Ya
data:
**[English]()** • [中文（中国大陆）‎](/wiki/Ya/zh-CN "Ya/zh-CN")

| ) [![Bamboo arrow.png](/images/d/de/Bamboo_arrow.png)](/wiki/File:Bamboo_arrow.png) |                                                        |
| ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------ |
| Name                                                                                | ya                                                     |
| Appearance                                                                          | bamboo arrow                                           |
| Damage vs. small                                                                    | 1d7                                                    |
| Damage vs. large                                                                    | 1d7                                                    |
| To-hit bonus                                                                        | +1                                                     |
| Weapon skill                                                                        | [bow](/wiki/Bow "Bow")                                 |
| Size                                                                                | [one-handed](/wiki/One-handed "One-handed")            |
| Base price                                                                          | 4 [zm](/wiki/Zorkmid "Zorkmid") (+10/positive enchant) |
| Weight                                                                              | [1](/wiki/Weight "Weight")                             |
| Material                                                                            | [metal](/wiki/Metal "Metal")                           |

The **ya** is a projectile weapon that appears in *[Nethack](/wiki/Nethack "Nethack")*. It is a type of [arrow](/wiki/Arrow "Arrow") designed for use with a [yumi](/wiki/Yumi "Yumi"). Ya arrowheads are made of [metal](/wiki/Metal "Metal"), and ya appear as **bamboo arrows** when unidentified.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)
- [2 Description](#Description)
- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)
- [4 History](#History)
- [5 Origin](#Origin)
- [6 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)
- [7 References](#References)

## Generation

In addition to random generation, [Samurai](/wiki/Samurai "Samurai") will always start the game with 26 to 45 ya.

## Description

Samurai firing ya from a [yumi](/wiki/Yumi "Yumi") gain a +1 [multishot](/wiki/Multishot "Multishot") bonus.

## Strategy

Ya are high-quality projectiles for most bow-wielding roles on paper: they deal the most base damage out of all arrows (1d7 versus 1d6 for normal arrows), are the only arrows to have a [to-hit](/wiki/To-hit "To-hit") bonus and are inherently [erosion](/wiki/Erosion "Erosion")-proof. Samurai are the most likely to get any use out of them in practice, due to their [multishot](/wiki/Multishot "Multishot") bonus and starting stack of ya; while other bow-wielding characters such as [Rangers](/wiki/Ranger "Ranger") may consider them, ya are only marginally better than the much more common [elven arrows](/wiki/Elven_arrow "Elven arrow") for those roles. Like with most projectiles that mulch, long-term use of ya requires gathering a fairly large stack of them, as well as maximizing [luck](/wiki/Luck "Luck") and securing a [luck item](/wiki/Luck_item "Luck item"), before committing [scrolls of enchant weapon](/wiki/Scrolls_of_enchant_weapon "Scrolls of enchant weapon") to enchanting them.

## History

The ya is introduced alongside the yumi in [NetHack 3.1.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.1.0 "NetHack 3.1.0"). In [NetHack 3.0.10](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.10 "NetHack 3.0.10") and previous versions, including some variants based on those versions, Samurai start with a stack of [shuriken](/wiki/Shuriken "Shuriken").[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Ya (arrow)](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ya_\(arrow\) "wikipedia:Ya (arrow)")***

*Ya* are a real world arrow type used by Japanese archers, around 85-110 centimeters (33-43 inches) compared to the 75-90 centimeters (30-35 inches) of the 'standard' arrow. Their size is designed specifically for the very large *yumi*. The to-hit bonus may suggest *ya* with a [bodkin point](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bodkin_point "wikipedia:Bodkin point"), a common medieval war-time arrow in many societies designed to penetrate armor (particularly [chain mail](/wiki/Chain_mail "Chain mail")).

## Encyclopedia entry

The arrow of choice of the samurai, ya are made of very straight bamboo, and are tipped with hardened steel.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [u\_init.c in NetHack 3.0.0, line 200](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.0.0/u_init.c#line200 "Source:NetHack 3.0.0/u init.c")

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")

Ya

From NetHackWiki

English

 • 中文（中国大陆）‎
)
Name ya
Appearance bamboo arrow
Damage vs. small 1d7
Damage vs. large 1d7
To-hit bonus +1
Weapon skill bow
Size one-handed
Base price 4 zm
(+10/positive
enchant)
Weight 1
Material metal

The ya is a projectile weapon that appears in Nethack. It is a type of arrow designed for use with a yumi. Ya arrowheads are made of metal, and ya appear as bamboo arrows when unidentified.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Description
  • 3 Strategy
  • 4 History
  • 5 Origin
  • 6 Encyclopedia entry
  • 7 References

Generation

In addition to random generation, Samurai will always start the game with 26 to 45 ya.

Description

Samurai firing ya from a yumi gain a +1 multishot bonus.

Strategy

Ya are high-quality projectiles for most bow-wielding roles on paper: they deal the most base damage out of all arrows (1d7 versus 1d6 for normal arrows), are the only arrows to have a to-hit bonus and are inherently erosion-proof. Samurai are the most likely to get any use out of them in practice, due to their multishot bonus and starting stack of ya; while other bow-wielding characters such as Rangers may consider them, ya are only marginally better than the much more common elven arrows for those roles. Like with most projectiles that mulch, long-term use of ya requires gathering a fairly large stack of them, as well as maximizing luck and securing a luck item, before committing scrolls of enchant weapon to enchanting them.

History

The ya is introduced alongside the yumi in NetHack 3.1.0. In NetHack 3.0.10 and previous versions, including some variants based on those versions, Samurai start with a stack of shuriken.[1]

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Ya (arrow)

Ya are a real world arrow type used by Japanese archers, around 85-110 centimeters (33-43 inches) compared to the 75-90 centimeters (30-35 inches) of the 'standard' arrow. Their size is designed specifically for the very large yumi. The to-hit bonus may suggest ya with a bodkin point, a common medieval war-time arrow in many societies designed to penetrate armor (particularly chain mail).

Encyclopedia entry

The arrow of choice of the samurai, ya are made of very straight bamboo, and are tipped with hardened steel.

References

  1. ↑ u_init.c in NetHack 3.0.0, line 200

The '''ya''' is a projectile weapon that appears in ''[[Nethack]]''. It is a type of [[arrow]] designed for use with a [[yumi]]. Ya arrowheads are made of [[metal]], and ya appear as '''bamboo arrows''' when unidentified.

==Generation==
In addition to random generation, [[Samurai]] will always start the game with 26 to 45 ya.

==Description==
Samurai firing ya from a [[yumi]] gain a +1 [[multishot]] bonus.

==Strategy==
Ya are high-quality projectiles for most bow-wielding roles on paper: they deal the most base damage out of all arrows (1d7 versus 1d6 for normal arrows), are the only arrows to have a [[to-hit]] bonus and are inherently [[erosion]]-proof. Samurai are the most likely to get any use out of them in practice, due to their [[multishot]] bonus and starting stack of ya; while other bow-wielding characters such as [[Ranger]]s may consider them, ya are only marginally better than the much more common [[elven arrow]]s for those roles. Like with most projectiles that mulch, long-term use of ya requires gathering a fairly large stack of them, as well as maximizing [[luck]] and securing a [[luck item]], before committing [[scrolls of enchant weapon]] to enchanting them.

==History==
The ya is introduced alongside the yumi in [[NetHack 3.1.0]]. In [[NetHack 3.0.10]] and previous versions, including some variants based on those versions, Samurai start with a stack of [[shuriken]].{{refsrc|nethack=3.0.0|u_init.c|200}}

==Origin==
{{wikipedia|Ya (arrow)}}
''Ya'' are a real world arrow type used by Japanese archers, around 85-110 centimeters (33-43 inches) compared to the 75-90 centimeters (30-35 inches) of the 'standard' arrow. Their size is designed specifically for the very large ''yumi''. The to-hit bonus may suggest ''ya'' with a [[wikipedia:Bodkin point|bodkin point]], a common medieval war-time arrow in many societies designed to penetrate armor (particularly [[chain mail]]).

==Encyclopedia entry==
{{encyclopedia|
The arrow of choice of the samurai, ya are made of very straight bamboo, and are tipped with hardened steel.
}}
